_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Cherokee Nitrogen Company A? Executive Summary

1.0    Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies
We at Cherokee Nitrogen are strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is demonstrated by our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at out facility.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

2.0    Cherokee Nitrogen Company and Regulated Substances
Our facilityA?s primary activities encompass the manufacture of ammonia and related processes.  Ammonia is a natural part of the life process.  It is produced internally by all humans and mammals to process essential proteins.  Ammonia is one of the most widely used industrial chemicals in the world, and is commonly used to purify water and refrigerate foods.

The company is a supplier to the fertilizer, explosives, and commercial industries by manufacturing ammonium nitrate, ammonium nitrate solutions, and other products.   Cherokee Nitrogen markets its fertilizers to distributors, dealers, national farm retail chains, regional farm cooperatives, and other fertilizer producers for ultimate sale and delivery to farmers.

We have four regulated substances present at our facility.  These substances include anhydrous ammonia, ammonia solutions (> 20%), chlorine, and sulfur dioxide.  Anhydrous ammonia is used to manufacture nitric acid (<80 percent).  Aqueous ammonia is contained within the urea and ammonium nitrate solutions.  Chlorine is used to treat the incoming process water prior to use by the facility.  Sulfur dioxide is used to treat the outgoing process water prior to discharge from the facility.

Typically, the facility manufactures two types of ammonium nitrate solutions:  industrial A? grade (83 weight percent) ammonium nitrate solution, and a high pressure solution

consisting of 24 to 25 percent ammonia and 69 to 70 percent ammonium nitrate.  The industrial grade ammonium nitrate is used as a primary building block for commercial explosives and blasting agents.  Without this product, the mining of precious metals and gems, coal for power and concrete for construction would be much less safe and much more expensive. 

As this RMP will illustrate, our accidental release prevention programs and our emergency response planning efforts help us effectively manage any potential hazards posed by these regulated substances.

3.0    Accidental Release Prevention Program
Our facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention requirements set out under 40 CFR part 68 of the EPA.  This facility was designed and constructed in accordance with ASME, Section 8, 1955 and 1979 editions.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at out stationary source.

3.1    Process Safety Information
Cherokee Nitrogen maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

3.2    Process Hazard Analysis
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with our processes are indentified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analysis is HAZOP.  The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations and are revalidated at a regular interval of every five years.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  The most recent PHA/update was performed on 2/4/09.
    
3.3    Operating Procedures
For the purpose of safely conducting activities within our covered processes, Cherokee Nitrogen maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, t

emporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the process.

3.4    Training
Cherokee Nitrogen has a comprehensive training program in place to ensure that employees operating processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years and more frequently as needed.

3.5    Mechanical Integrity
Cherokee Nitrogen carries out highly documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others:  pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and pumps.
    
Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

3.6    Management of Change 
Written procedures are in place at Cherokee Nitrogen to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The most recent review/revision of Management of Change procedures was performed on 2/20/09.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal wit4h the modification.

3.7    Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Cherokee Nitrogen.  The most recent review was performed on 4/27/09.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into opera

tion.

3.8    Compliance Audits
Cherokee Nitrogen conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on 8/18/09.  These audits are carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

3.9    Incident Investigation
Cherokee Nitrogen promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are under taken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of five years.

3.10    Employee Participation
Cherokee Nitrogen truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, our employees have access to all information created as part of the facilityA?s implementation of the RMP rule, including information resulting from process hazard analysis in particular.

3.11    Contractors
On occasion, our company hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of safety performance of the contractor is carried out.  Cherokee Nitrogen has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards to related the contractorA?s work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

4.0    Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

4.1    Anhydrous Ammonia
Several process controls are in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check

valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, emergency back-up power, back-up pumps, ruptured disks, excess flow devices, and water cannons.

4.2    Ammonia Solutions (>20%)
Several process controls are likewise in place to prevent and/or mitigate accidental releases of aqueous ammonia.  These controls include vents, relief valves, check valves, manual and automatic shut-offs, interlocks, alarms, back-up pumps, and excess flow devices.

5.0    Five A? year Accident History 
Cherokee Nitrogen Company has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to our stringest release prevention policies, the number of accidental releases has been reduced to a minimum.
    
There have been 3 accidental releases of regulated substances from our facility within the last 5 years.  The following is a brief summary of significant accidental chemical releases involving materials covered under EPSA?s RMP Rule during the previous five years.

5.1    Anhydrous Ammonia
During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen Company had (1) accidental anhydrous ammonia release and it took place on 01/27/2005 and involved 5 pounds of anhydrous ammonia. No deaths or injuries occurred offsite as a result of this accident. Onsite, there was (1) injury and no deaths. 
 
5.2    Ammonia Solutions (>20%)
During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen Company has had (2) accidental ammonia solutions releases.  These incidents took place on 3/12/07 and 10/28/07.  Each accident included 31 pounds of ammonia solution.  No deaths or injuries occurred offsite as a result of these accidents. Onsite, each incident resulted in (1) injury and no deaths.

5.3    Chlorine
During the past five years, Cherokee Nitrogen Company has not had an accidental chlorine release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

5.4    Sulfur Dioxide
During the past five years,

Cherokee Nitrogen Company has not had an accidental sulfur dioxide release resulting in on-site or off-site consequences, including deaths, injuries, significant property damage, environmental damage, off-site evacuation, or sheltering in place.

6.0    Emergency Response Programs
Cherokee Nitrogen maintains a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, our emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within out processes that would require a modified emergency response.

Colbert County LEPC is the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) with which our emergency plan has been coordinated and verified.

7.0    Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Cherokee Nitrogen Company continually strives to improve and upgrade operating procedures, replace or maintain equipment, and develop and implement safety improvement projects.  Several developments and findings have resulted from the implementation of the various elements of out accidental release prevention program.  Some of the major steps taken to improve safety at our facility include:  installation of security/safety cables on all overhead chain operated valves; American Red Cross CPR and AED training; semi-annual third party safety inspections and audits with corrective action and follow up; establishing safety goals; plant wide monthly safety awareness meetings which focus on safety needs and input from all employees, and increase in site security measures.
    
These activities are implemented and reflect current practices established at Cherokee Nitrogen.
